Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Small-Molecule Enantiopurity Measurement in Living Cells as a Method to Accelerate Biocatalyst Discovery
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Measurement and Imaging program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation funds this project. Professor Jennifer Heemstra of the University of Utah is developing methods to rapidly assay reaction conditions for the selective production of small molecules. This research aids in the use of enzymes to catalyze key steps in the synthesis of therapeutics and other high value chemicals. The reactions currently used to generate these products often require metal-containing catalysts and organic solvents. The disposal of both catalyst and solvent pose an environmental hazard. In contrast, enzyme catalysts are environmentally benign, as the enzymes themselves are non-toxic, and they are used in water rather than organic solvents. The broader impacts of this research are demonstrated in multiple ways. This research provides training to high school, undergraduate, and graduate students. Also included is an outreach activity aimed at improving the retention of college women in STEM disciplines. The research has potential to benefit society by facilitating the discovery of new, environmentally benign methods for the synthesis of high-value chemicals such as small-molecule therapeutics.

The overarching objectives of this proposal are to explore methods to rapidly generate DNA biosensors for small-molecule targets of interest and to deploy these sensors in living bacterial cells. Methods are developed to enable the selection of DNA biosensors for an enzymatically-produced small molecule that is a pharmaceutical intermediate. The proposed research explores the ability of fluorescent DNA biosensors to be transfected into bacterial cells and used to quantify the intracellular concentration of a target analyte.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Enzymes are finding increasingly wide use to catalyze key steps in the synthesis of therapeutics and other high value chemicals. The reactions traditionally used to generate these products often require metal-containing catalysts and organic solvents. The disposal of both catalyst and solvent pose an environmental hazard. In contrast, enzyme catalysts are environmentally benign, as the enzymes themselves are non-toxic, and they are used in water rather than organic solvents. However, many reacitons require a level of selectivity referred to as enantioselectivity - the ability to produce a molecule with a single handedness when two different options are possible. While enzymes are extremely effective at achieving enantioselectivity in nature, they must be engineered in the lab to achieve this same selectivity on the substrates needed to generate therapeutics and other compounds of interest. With support from NSF, we developed a high-throughput assay that can rapidly determine the enantioselectivity of small-molecule mixtures. This assay leverages the ability of DNA molecules to bind to specific small-molecule targets and convert their concentration into an optical signal. It also harnesses the fact that DNA itself has handedness, and thus can be used to individually report the concentration of each enantiomer of the desired product molecule. To ensure broad use, we designed the assay to utilize flow cytometry instruments that offer exceptionally high throughput and are widely available in universities and industrial settings. With this assay in hand, we are now poised to carry out the engineering of enzymes capable of producing interesting small-molecule targets with high enantioselectivity.

This project has also contributed to workforce development. Specifically, through the activities carried out with NSF funding, high school, undergraduate, and graduate students have received training in cutting-edge research techniques as well as key skills including science communication and leadership. The project also supported an outreach activity aimed at improving the retention of college women in STEM disciplines. The research has potential to benefit society by facilitating the discovery of new, environmentally benign methods for the synthesis of high-value chemicals such as small-molecule therapeutics.
